summary:
“Am I your dad!!?” Billy shouted. Danny paused. Took a deep breath in and out before turning to him.

“I’m gonna need you to back up, and explain. Please.”

 

Or, what happens when a twelve year old masquerading as an adult superhero calls his guardian, an adult who can also turn into a child superhero, on speaker phone, in front of the Justice League.

How it started... and how it's going.

What happens when your coworker whose child had died and came back comes up to you and asks for advice as a presumed fellow parent whose child died and came back, but really you're a panicking 12 year old? This, apparently.

Ta da! Next chapter is here! More identity shenanigans, a little bit of Jason in Fawcett, the Justice League, clones, and freaking people out.

Billy has therapy with Jazz, and confesses something that expands his family.

"I thought Marvel, Phantom, Phantasm, and he had it handled,” Tim replied disgruntledly.

“Phantasm who?”

“Phantasm me!”

“I travel a lot, and I would stop and settle down around you if you asked, but I also want to know if you’d like to travel with me,” Kon looked at her, blue eyes wide, and Elle had to resist the urge to bundle him in blankets and protect him from everything that ever hurt him.

What does it take to soar above the clouds? Well, it really depends on how you fly, and Billy knows it more than most others.

A working father is a stressed father, especially when work is of the paranormal kind. Jason babysits, threatens to get Billy adopted by Batman, and holds a meeting. Not necessarily in that order.

If there was one thing Captain Marvel hated about fighting in an urban environment, it was the collateral.

"J’onn… wasn’t quite sure why they were all there, to be honest. Phantom had a crown. This, on its own, would not be an issue. But instead, Phantom and Marvel treated it as a big deal, which caused the others around them to treat it as a big deal."

Family can be a half dead adult, a psychiatrist who gave therapy to her own family, a plant witch, the reincarnation of an ancient pharaoh, the Champion of Magic, and a crime lord.

This wasn’t Amity Park where the only person around with plant powers was her. This wasn’t Amity Park where the ambient ectoplasm from the portal made her powers extremely reactionary to even mildly strong emotions. This wasn’t Amity Park. This was Gotham, and there was a very well known, very powerful plant user with a vendetta against people and corporations that harmed nature.

“Any plans for today?”

Billy raised an eyebrow. “No. Besides my usual patrols, that is,”

“Great! We have a lunch date,”

“With who?”

“That’s a surprise,”

“This is the way the world ends. Not with a bang but a whimper,” - T.S. Elliot, The Hollow Men

Billy's secret is out.

There's one more important identity questions to answer.

Batman's allergic to sharing his thoughts, Superman's bad at handling things when they hit too close to home, Flash sometimes forgets that people don't think as quick as him. They're all people. They all have flaws. But they're also heroes, they chose to be heroes, they chose to hold themselves to a higher standard, and they're going to do their damn best to meet it. So, as much as I love drama and emotionally charged situations... this ain't it. This is rational, intelligent people having a rational, intelligent conversation. And it works!

It had started simply, as most complicated things did. It had started with Billy Batson, currently as Captain Marvel, opening his stupid mouth.

 

        “I know someone.” He said, much to his immediate regret when Batman suddenly zeroed in on him. As well as the rest of the League in the meeting room. When Batman had called a meeting, Marvel hadn’t thought it would be Batman showing an extremely grainy picture of a ghost riding a motorcycle in Gotham and declaring him the newest menace to society. A mysterious being who glowed, and seemed to be entirely impenetrable to attacks. Until Constantine had shown up, complaining and cursing ‘stupid motherfuckin’ ghosts bothering me, it’s the fuckin’ middle of the night’, and performed an exorcism. Batman was entirely displeased with being caught unawares, especially in his own territory. So, he had come to the League, presenting this new, mysterious threat that had dodged him within his own territory and that he knew practically nothing about. The League had been lamenting their lack of knowledge of this particularly dangerous enemy, before Marvel spoke up.

 

        Because Marvel, in all his twelve-year-old-masquerading-as-an-adult glory had decided to bring up the one thing, the one person, he didn’t want to bring up in conversation with the League. Batman narrowed his eyes.

 

        “Who.” He growled out. And Marvel, or more honestly Billy in that situation, froze. Because he knew for a fact he could not lie for shit. Any misdirection would be suspicious, and he couldn’t backtrack out of it without giving a reason, and I’m actually a twelve year old masquerading as an adult, and was previously homeless until my current guardian took me in and whenever he transforms into Phantom he looks like he’s fourteen again because he’s a half ghost, but he would also know the most despite retiring from being a vigilante at eighteen and doesn’t want to be brought back into the fold unless it had to do with ghosts, and right now it really did have to do with ghosts, but calling his Dad guardian to come help was embarrassing. Aaand, he had been silent too long and they were all staring at him.

 

        Marvel breathed out deeply and mustered up both the Courage of Achillese and the Courage of Billy Batson for what was going to come. “I’ll call him,” he said and brought out his communicator.

 

        “Your League communicator frequency is not to be given out, Captain,” Batman rumbled dangerously.

 

        “I needed to give it. For emergencies,” Marvel replied. Danny had insisted that Billy have a line to him, even as a League member in case he needed help. “Just because you can do it without help doesn’t mean you should. I’m here for you, kid.” Marvel let Danny’s words ring briefly through his head, words that had been agreed with by Solomon, and dialed Danny’s number into his communicator. He avoided looking up at the Leaguers staring at him, feeling their gazes burn into his head like they all had Superman’s heat vision. When the line connected, he immediately began talking before Danny could get a word out. “Hey Phantom! I’m with the League right now. A ghost was causing some trouble in Gotham a little while back, and we were wondering for general information? Whatever you’re willing to give.” He added at the end, knowing Danny kept ghostly information close to his chest when it came to strangers.

 

        A hissing, static noise erupted from the communicator, and Marvel saw the Leaguers around him jolt in surprise before the static died down into a voice. “Sure!” Phantom’s young, static laced voice came through. It never failed to amaze Billy at the difference in Danny and Phantom’s voiced. Danny was an adult, with a job and paid taxes and sent Billy to school, with a low but soft voice. Phantom was light and curious, a voice made to be heard over crowds and chaos. “What can I do for ya’?”

 

        Batman leaned closer to Marvel (when the hell did Batman get beside him, what the fuck?) and spoke. “Can you identify a ghost based on the description I’m about to give you?” And… what? Why was Batman pulling out the less growly nice voice that he used… for…kids. Oh. The League was probably entirely under the impression Marvel had called a random kid to ask for ghost advice. Shiiit, how was he going to explain his way out of this one?

 

        “Yeah, sure. Anybody that’d come to the mortal realm is probably one of the usual suspects.” Phantom confirmed. Batman just grunted.

 

        “He had a motorcycle-”

 

        “And a living Shadow, blond hair, and a leather jacket. Man, I knew Johnny had gotten up to something with how he was grumbling. I thought it was just a failed attempt to get back with Kitty.”

 

        “...Johnny.”

 

        “Yup! Johnny 13, delinquent extraordinaire. He didn’t hurt anyone, right?”

 

        And oh, did Billy know that tone. Before Batman could reply (he was cutting off Batman, oh gods) Marvel cut in. “You know he’s not your responsibility, right?” The silence on the other end spoke multitudes. “It’s not your fault what he chooses to do.”

 

        “I could stop him though. I have stopped him.” Phantom grumbled.

 

        “You took a step back from that. You deserve to live your afterlife how you choose. Which is why the League is asking for help, because even if you know you can handle it, doesn’t mean you should have to.”

 

        There was a ringing silence in the Justice League meeting room. For the first time since he dialed in Danny’s number, he looked up. All of the Leaguers were staring at him, some with curiosity, others intrigue, and a few with… awe?

 

        “...’S not fair when you bring out the Wisdom of Solomon. How am I supposed to win arguments like this?” Phantom grumbled.

 

        “With logic.”

 

        “Shut up.”

 

        Marvel couldn’t hold back what was probably a very goofy smile. He loved Dad Danny and the way he never treated Billy like a stupid kid. He had parents, and they died. He had foster parents, and they, along with the system, failed him. And now he had Danny, the embodiment of a Guardian.

 

        “So, back on subject,” Phantom began, “Natural portals between the Infinite Realms, where most ectoplasmic entities reside, are fairly rare, and most quote-unquote ‘summoning spells’ don’t work due to the natural interference between the realms and the living plane. Johnny probably just got lucky with the natural portal and felt like causing trouble. That being said, there have been… misconceptions about ghosts. We’re not inherently bad. The trouble makers are the ones that slip out the most, and given that’s what most people’s experiences are, a lot of people and so called professionals can be.. rather bigoted. Most of us are peaceful. We just want to live our afterlives, alright?”

 

        The League was silent once more. “In the event this happens again, how can we protect ourselves from malignant,” Batman paused briefly, “ghosts?”

 

        “...Magic works best. Most ghosts just want to cause mischief, not death. We already know what that feels like,” And oh, the League flinched bad at the reminder that they were talking to someone who died, much less what they thought was a dead kid. The only sign of it affecting Batman was the minute tightening of his jaw that Marvel could only see with how close he was. “Other than magic? Like effects like; a ghost or some other form of dead would be your best chance.”

 

        Marvel smiled and began to talk. “Thanks for sharing, Phantom. I know this wasn’t easy.”

 

        “Eh,” Phantom replied, sounding bashful, “I just don’t want you or anyone else to deal with an overshadowed Superman.”

 

        “I think I’d win that fight.”

 

        “Sure.”

 

        “No need to sound sceptical! I’m offended.” Marvel replied in mock indignation.

 

        “Yeah, okay. You’d win,” Danny admitted with an amount of grudging fondness. “Off topic, I’ve got a craving for chinese, can we order that tonight?”

 

        Marvel grinned, a rush of mischievous glee running through him. “I don’t know, can we?”

 

        “Shut up. When are you getting home?” Danny asked. Marvel glanced up at Batman.

 

        “This was all we needed Marvel for,” Batman spoke.

 

        “I’ll finish up here and then complete a quick patrol. So, less than an hour. That sound good?” Marvel asked.

 

        “Yup! See you soon! Love you,” Phantom replied easily.

 

        “Love you too,” Marvel replied instinctively, and the communicator chirped as the call ended. He smiled softly and looked up. The smile quickly fell into discomfort at the fact that everyone was staring at him. Marvel looked up at Batman, who was still looming over his shoulder. “Can I…” His gaze flicked back over to the still staring Leaguers, “Go now?”

 

        Superman seemed to blink out of a stupor. “Oh, yeah, of course,” he said, “Thank you for both you and Phantom’s help.” And here Superman gave him a weird look, one that was weirdly soft and full of awe.

 

        “Meeting adjourned,” Batman growled, “If you encounter any of these ghosts, call in for an available magic user’s assistance.” With that, Batman gave Marvel an inscrutable look before sweeping out of the room. Marvel stood up, deliberately avoiding the eyes of the still staring Leaguers, why were they looking at him like that? So Marvel turned around casually, and walked purposefully to the door. The room was still silent and anxiety prickled at his spine. Why were they all still looking at him? Just as he was closing the door behind him, he heard Flash speak up.

 

        “I can’t believe Captain Marvel is a dad.”

 

        The door closed as Marvel tripped forward. He was a what??!

        The walk to the zeta tubes passed in a blur. Patrol in Fawcett was a haze and he helped a cat out of a tree, helped carry a nice man’s shopping bags, and stopped one mugging before he went home. When he called the wizard’s name and turned back into Billy, it was like his mind was zapped back into him. He dashed up the apartment steps (the elevator never worked) and burst into the apartment to the sight of Danny laying out an array of takeout containers.

 

        “Hey Billy! How was-”

 

        “Am I your dad!!?” Billy shouted. Danny paused. Took a deep breath in and out before turning to him.

 

        “I’m gonna need you to back up, and explain. Please.”

   For Billy, it started with the Rock of Eternity. Which was how his career as Captain Marvel started as well, so maybe it was a bit auspicious (Sam taught him that word when she taught him about Tarot). 

 

   Billy didn’t spend a lot of time at the Rock of Eternity. Sure, it was secure, safe, and away from the elements, a big step up from a condemned apartment with doors that didn’t lock and windows that only closed halfway, but there were too many downsides. Time was weird at the Rock. A minute there could be an hour, a day, one time Billy lost a whole week of Earth time. Thank the gods there weren’t any emergencies that Captain Marvel was needed for that week. He did, however, miss a Monitor shift. Any other job wouldn’t accept ‘unexpected time dilation’ as an actual reason for absence; the Justice League, however, was different. But Billy only spent as much at the Rock of Eternity as he had to. Also, the Rock felt… weird. Maybe it was all the ancient evil artifacts that were stored here. Maybe it was the Sins’ statues. Maybe it was the Rock itself. Or the fact that the Wizard died here. Or the doorways.

 

   Doors that lined the walls, some even hiding on floors or the ceilings. Some led to other rooms, like normal doors. Only half of those Billy could reasonably assume were actually at the Rock of Eternity. So many were just… weird. And with so many back entrances, Billy was constantly revising whether or not the Rock was really safe. Only by virtue of every other magic user Billy had ever met giving him A Look of something between disbelief and terror when he had talked about having access to the Rock of Eternity swayed him back to the idea that it was safe. Constantine himself had replied to Billy, “What the absolute fuck, that shit’s supposed to be a myth, and I’ve gone to five different hells, what the fuck kid”.

 

   So, doors. Half led to rooms. The other half… apparently led to instances like these?

 

   Billy stared at the door that had opened. From the other side. The other person, the man, looked like he wasn’t expecting this either. Billy catalogued the situation, just like Batman had talked about. One person, rather tall, scruffy short black hair, piercing blue eyes, vaguely familiar, and a really odd aura. Matching the swirling green-purple dimension (?) Billy could see behind the man and the door he had just opened. Exit routes. The door behind the man, and the opening to this crevice behind him. It was empty otherwise, precisely the reason Billy chose to store some of his more precious items here.

 

   Weapons? Magic, of course. But he doubted a picture of his parents and Tawky Tawny the stuffed tiger plush he kept here really counted. So, unknown situation, little to no weapons, what would Batman do?

 

   …Try to learn more about his situation. So Billy took a stabilizing breath, pasted on a smile and said brightly, “Hi there! Can I help you with something?”

   For Danny, it started with him wanting to take an Ancients damned break.    No one looked at him. No one seemed willing to give him an answer. Except Batman.

 

   “What do you want to happen?” He asked lowly, and Billy couldn’t help but smile at him.

 

   “Preferably? Nothing. Nothing changes. I come up for my Monitor Duty shifts, I help with missions, I come as backup when asked, and just help however I can,”

 

   “What about school?” Flash asked.

 

   “Online, to catch up for the years I missed and to leave room for superhero things,”

 

   “You said you’re not homeless anymore. Do you have a guardian?” Diana asked.

   “What about friends?” Green Arrow asked. 

 

   “Well,” Billy rubbed at the back of his neck, “I think of you as my friends. And I understand how that might’ve changed for you after,” Billy waved his hand vaguely, “This.    “I play the fool, but that doesn’t mean I am one,” Hal turned up his nose playfully.

   “Damn! Coming for me too, J’onn?”

 

   “I speak nothing but the truth,”

 

   Everyone, except Batman, chuckled at them, but Billy was pretty sure that he saw Batman smirk a little in amusement.

 

   “So that’s it?” Billy asked. 

 

   “This does feel… a little easy?” Superman said, sounding a little baffled.

 

   “Why does it need to be hard?” Zatanna asked, crossing her arms.

 

   “It doesn’t need to be, but I gotta be honest I expected this to be more… emotional? Loud?” Flash said.

 

   “It shouldn’t be,” Billy crossed his arms. “Like, in my worst case scenarios I imagined there’d be a lot of shouting, but worst case scenario doesn’t mean likely case scenario. I can’t say we’re all adults here,” Billy joked slightly and hoped it wasn’t too soon, “But I can say we’re all mature, rational people. We all know shouting isn’t helpful. We all know that emotion and logic aren’t always in line with each other. I hoped that we could talk through this instead of, y’know, shouting, and we did,”

 

   “You should know better,” Batman growled at the people at the table, “And you didn’t prove me wrong. Good. Secret identities are just that: secret. We allowed for these secrets, and being mad when something unexpected happens is foolish. Captain Marvel is an exemplary member of the League who has proven time and time again to be both a good hero and a good person. The Justice League defends everyone, regardless of age, species, gender, or elsewise. It makes sense that anyone can defend people, regardless of age, species, gender, or elsewise. Agreed?”

 

   No one spoke out against Batman. “Good. Any further issues can be handled individually. Dismissed,” There was a pause, where no one moved, and then Zatanna stood up.

 

   “It was nice seeing you, Billy. Tell your dad hi for me,” And then she walked out.

 

   “Yeah, uh, nice getting to know you better, Cap. I’m going to ask for all the stories during Monitor Duty, though,” Flash grinned tentatively, and then brightened when Billy smiled back. From there it was a steady stream of people leaving, tentative goodbyes backed by relieved smiles when Billy didn’t dismiss them out of hand. He didn’t know why they thought he would. Then again, their trust in him was shaken. And they’d learned that his trust in them wasn’t as strong as they thought it was.

 

   But maybe… no they would learn to trust each other. They’d learn, and it’d be stronger than it was before. It wouldn’t necessarily be easy , but often the hard things had some of the best results. Billy smiled to himself and let his shoulders fall as he finally relaxed.

 

   That went… really good. Better than he expected it to. Better than his worst case scenario, better than his most likely case scenario, too. This was… good. It was good. He was good. Do good and good will follow. Billy appreciated the almost irony of his own phrase coming back to him in the best of ways.

 

   “Billy,” 

 

   Billy yelped and jumped slightly. Gods damnit, he’d forgotten about Batman! Captain Marvel cleared his throat. “Batman,”

 

   “I understand your motivations for keeping your situation hidden,” He paused and Billy stared at him. Was Batman waiting for an answer?

 

   “Yes?”

 

   “I hope that the reactions of the League allow for you to… come to us, if you have an issue again,”

 

   “If I can’t handle it on my own, sure,”

 

   Batman stared at Billy. Billy stared at Batman. Batman sighed. “Billy. I’m saying… as a father, that if you need assistance, I’m here for you. In whatever capacity you’ll allow,”

 

   Billy couldn’t help but smile softly. Batman was usually so stern and confident, but Billy really did like to see the human parts of him. The man who asked for help only when it came to his children, and stumbled over his words, and tried so, so hard even when it didn’t work. Maybe especially when it didn’t work.

 

   “I’ll keep that in mind,” Billy said, “Promise,”

 

   Batman nodded firmly and swept past Billy, the end of his black cape swirling past like a flurry of socially awkward shadows.

 

   Billy stood alone in the meeting room for a moment, before drifting over to the windows. This side of the Watchtower was currently facing away from Earth, so all there was to see were stars.

 

   Lights of stars and suns and planets, all glinting together in a beautiful tapestry of ink. Together but still so far apart. How amazing was it, to live on a planet with so many people. To live on a planet saturated with magic. To live on a planet with humans and animals and Gods and aliens and friends. Of all the places in the universe, of all the people in the universe, Billy was here. 

 

   Wasn’t life amazing?

 

   Billy’s phone, that he’d for once made sure to have on him as Captain Marvel, buzzed. Billy pulled it out of a pocket, which he was pretty sure his suit hadn’t had before today, and looked at the notifications. Danny had texted him. Billy unlocked his phone and pulled up the text.

   Billy smiled and texted his reply.

 

We’re done. It actually went better than I thought it would.

Yeah, me too.

 

   Billy smiled and looked back out at the stars. They really were beautiful. Life was beautiful. And Billy was doing great. His phone buzzed again.

 

So how did they take, y’know, my whole situation?
